entry.title: CS61B-1:Java Intro, Classes
entry.content: Running a Java Program .java-> javac (compiler) -> .class (Java bytecode) -> java (Interpreter) -> runs .class file 1. safer (type checked) 2. faster (for machine to execute) 3. protect intellectual property Static Typing Statically Typed language All Variables have a declared type and type can never be changed Expressions have a type Compiler will check and make sure the type right before the program runs Pros and Cons Pros catch certain types of errors type errors never occur on end users easier to read and reason about the code run efficiently (no runtime type checking) Cons code is more verbose code is less general but it can be solved by generics Static vs. Non-Static Instance Variables and Object Instantiation Problem: Not all objects of a class are equal  => Approach1: create separate classes for each => redundancy  => Approach2: classes instantiated and instances hold data    e.g. Type ins = new Type(); Instance Members (Variables/Methods) = Non-Static Members (Variables/Methods) Constructors Parameterized instantiation Class (Static) Methods VS Instance (Non-Static) Methods Static Methods invoked using the class name Static Variables properties inherent to class itself accessed using name of class Instance Methods actions that can be taken only by a specific instance of a class Keyword this to refer to the current object Arrays of Object 2 steps of initializing arrays => First use new keyword to create the array (Dog[] dogs = new Dog[2]) => then use new again for each object that you want to put into the array The array index starts at 0 in Java Array.length Alternate way of defining array int[] numbers = new int[] {4, 7, 10}; The Enhanced For Loop12345678for (String s : a) { for (int j = 0; j < 3; j += 1) { System.out.println(s); if (s.contains("horse")) { break; } }} Summary of Terminology Instance Variables (Properties) Non-static Methods (Instance Methods) Constructors (How to instantiate the class)Declaration + Instantiation + Assignment + Invocation of Methods
